facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 13th July, 1956, of the Patna High Court in M. J. C. No. 404 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 13th July, 1956, of the Patna High Court in M. J. C. No. 404 of 1954. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India and S. P. Varma, for the Appellants.

facts.text: The appellant is a Corporation incorporated under the Damodar Valley Corporation Act XIV of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Corporation incorporated under the Damodar Valley Corporation Act XIV of 1948 and will hereinafter be referred to as the Corporation. It is a multipurpose Corporation, one of its objects being the construction of a number of dams in Bihar and Bengal with a view to controlling floods and utilising the stored water for purposes of generation of electricity.

facts.text: Corporation entered into an agreement with Messrs Hind Construction Ltd. and Messrs Patel Engineering Co. Ltd. on May 24, 1950, appointing them contractors for construction of Konar Dam.

anchor.surface_text: For the construction of the aforesaid Dam the Corporation entered into an agreement with Messrs Hind Construction Ltd. and Messrs Patel Engineering Co. Ltd. on May 24, 1950, and appointed them contractors for the aforesaid purpose. They will hereinafter be referred to as the Contractors.

facts.text: Supplementary agreement entered on March 10, 1951, amending cl. 8 of Part II of the original agreement.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of a change in the design of the Dam, it became necessary to enter into a supplementary agreement and on March 10, 1951, cl. 8 of Part II of the original agreement was amended and a fresh cl. 8 was substituted.

facts.text: Under amended cl. 8, Corporation agreed to make available equipment to contractors at actual price paid by Corporation excluding sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: Under the new cl. 8 of the agreement, as amended, the Corporation agreed to make available to the contractors such equipment as was necessary and suitable for the construction aforesaid. The Contractors are charged the actual price paid by the Corporation for the equipment and machinery thus made available, inclusive of freight and customs duty, if any, as also the cost of transport, but excluding sales tax.

facts.text: Equipment classified into Group A and Group B as per Schedule No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: The equipment thus supplied by the Corporation to the Contractors was classified into two groups, Group A and Group B, as detailed in Schedule No. 2.

facts.text: Machinery in Group A to be taken over by Corporation at residual value after completion of work.

anchor.surface_text: The machinery in Group A was to be taken over from the Contractors by the Corporation, after the completion of the work at their residual value which was to be calculated in the manner set out in the agreement.

facts.text: No dispute about Group B machinery, which became property of Contractors after full payment.

anchor.surface_text: The machinery in Group B was to become the property of the Contractors after its full price had been paid by them. No more need be said about the machinery in Group B, because there is no dispute about that group, the Contractors having accepted the position that Group B machinery had been sold to them.

facts.text: Controversy relates to machinery in Group A.

anchor.surface_text: The controversy now remaining between the parties relates to the machinery in Group A.

facts.text: Superintendent of Sales Tax, Hazaribagh, assessed Corporation under s. 13(5) of the Act for period April 1950 to March 1952 on August 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On August 12, 1952, the Superintendent of Sales Tax, Hazaribagh, assessed the Corporation under s. 13(5) of the Act for the period April, 1950 to March, 1952.

facts.text: Corporation appealed to Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax, order dated May 5, 1953 rejecting contention of no liability.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation went up in appeal to the Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax against the said order of assessment. By his order dated May 5, 1953, the Deputy Commissioner rejected the contention of the appellant as to its liability under the Act,

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner held supply of Group A equipment amounted to sale, not hire, and condition for taking over was repurchase.

anchor.surface_text: the Deputy Commissioner repelling the Corporations contentions based on the Act, held inter-alia that the supply of equipment in Group A of the agreement aforesaid amounted to a sale and was not a hire that the condition in the agreement for the taking over of the equipment on conditions laid down in the agreement was in its essence a condition of repurchase

facts.text: Board of Revenue rejected revisional application under s.24 on October 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation moved the Board of Revenue, Bihar, in its revisional jurisdiction under s. 24 of the Act. The Board of Revenue by its resolution dated October 1, 1953, rejected the revisional application and upheld the order of the authorities below.

facts.text: Corporation applied to Board of Revenue under s.25 on December 22, 1953 for reference to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Corporation made an application to the Board of Revenue under s. 25 of the Act for a reference to refer the following questions to the High Court at Patna, namely,... This application was made on December 22, 1953,

facts.text: On May 20, 1954, counsel for Corporation withdrew questions a and c, only question b referred to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: but when the application for making a reference to the High Court came up for hearing before the Board of Revenue on May 20, 1954, and after the parties had been heard, counsel for the Corporation sought leave of the Board to withdraw questions a and c from the proposed reference

facts.text: Patna High Court on July 13, 1956 held transaction amounted to sale under s.2(g).

anchor.surface_text: a Division Bench of the High Court... heard the reference and came to the conclusion by its judgment dated July 13, 1956, that the reference should be answered in the affirmative, namely, that the transaction in question amounted to a sale within the meaning of s. 2(g) of the Act.

facts.text: High Court rejected certificate for appeal under Art.132 on January 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment and order of the High Court dated January 31, 1957 - It was conceded by learned counsel for the petitioner that the case does not fulfill the requirements of Article 133(1) of the Constitution but the argument is that leave may be granted under Article 132

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal on March 31, 1958 under Art.136.

anchor.surface_text: Having failed to obtain the necessary certificate from the High Court, the Corporation moved this Court and obtained special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The leave was granted on March 31, 1958.

facts.text: Facts of the case have never been in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this case have never been in dispute and may shortly be stated as follows.

facts.text: Approximate cost of Group A machinery Rs. 42,63,305.

anchor.surface_text: The total approximate cost of the machinery in Group A is estimated to be Rs. 42,63,305.

facts.text: Corporation to recover cost of Group A equipment in eighteen equal instalments.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the machinery which shall have been delivered to the Contractor on or before the 31st of December 1950, their cost shall be recovered from the Contractor in eighteen equal instalments beginning with January 1951

facts.text: After recovery of approx two-thirds (Rs. 28,43,000), Corporation to consider taking over at residual value.

anchor.surface_text: that after approximately two thirds of total cost or an amount of Rs. 28,43,000 (Rupees twenty eight lakhs forty three thousand) approximately has been recovered from the Contractor on account of these equipments the Corporation will consider the date or dates when it could take over the equipments

facts.text: Supreme Court limited appeal to whether transaction is sale under the Act, rejecting additional grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The preliminary objection must, therefore, be allowed and the appeal limited to the question whether the transaction in question in this case amounted to a sale within the meaning of the Act.

obtained special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The leave was granted on March 31, 1958. Though the scope of the decision of the High Court under s. 25 of the Act on a reference made to it is limited, the Corporation has raised certain additional points of controversy, which did not form part of the decision of the High Court.

arguments.claim: Transaction is sale or hire purchase

anchor.surface_text: the sole question for determination in this appeal is whether, in respect of the machinery and equipments admittedly supplied by the Corporation to the Contractors, it was a mere contract of hiring, as contended on behalf of the appellant Corporation, or a sale or a hire purchase, as contended on behalf of the respondent State.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t lent to the companytractors in respect of which the companytractors had to be charged in terms of hiring, including interest on capital companyt and

arguments.claim: For determining contract category, court looks to substance not mere words; mere hiring is bailment without title

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that a mere contract of hiring, without more, is a species of the contract of bailment, which does not create a title in the bailee, but the law of hire purchase has undergone considerable development during the last half a century or more... It is equally well- settled that for the purpose of determining as to which category a particular contract comes under, the court will look at the substance of the agreement and not at the mere words describing the category.

arguments.claim: Test: binding obligation on hirer to purchase indicates sale not mere hire

anchor.surface_text: One of the tests to determine the question whether a particular agreement is a contract of mere hiring or whether it is a contract of purchase on a system of deferred payments of the purchase price is whether there is any binding obligation on the hirer to purchase the goods.

arguments.claim: Test: right reserved to hirer to return goods indicates no sale (citing Helby v. Matthews)

anchor.surface_text: Another useful test to determine such a controversy is whether there is a right reserved to the hirer to return the goods at any time during the subsistence of the contract. If there is such a right reserved, then clearly there is no contract of sale, vide Helby v. Matthews and others  1 .

arguments.claim: Applying tests: sale with repurchase condition; no right to return, bound to pay two-thirds price, spares responsibility shows title passed

anchor.surface_text: Applying these two tests to the transaction in the present case, it becomes clear that it was a case of sale of goods with a condition of repurchase on certain conditions depending upon the satisfaction of the Corporation as to whether the residual life of the machinery or the equipment was not less than one-third of the standard life in accordance with the terms agreed between the parties.

holdings.text: The additional grounds of attack raised by the Corporation (not a dealer, proviso to s.2(g) ultra vires, Act ultra vires) are not open in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, a preliminary objection was raised on behalf of the respondent that the additional grounds of attack were not open to the Corporation in this Court. It is, therefore, necessary first to determine whether the additional grounds of attack set out above are open to the Corporation. In our opinion, those additional grounds are not open.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grounds never raised before authorities below or High Court; High Court under s.25 exercised advisory jurisdiction limited to referred question; even special leave under Art.136 cannot expand scope beyond High Court's decision.

holdings.text: The appeal is limited to the question whether the transaction amounted to a sale within the meaning of the Act, with the preliminary objection upheld.

anchor.surface_text: The preliminary objection must, therefore, be allowed and the appeal limited to the question whether the transaction in question in this case amounted to a sale within the meaning of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court could not opine beyond referred question; appeal sits over that limited decision.

holdings.text: The transaction regarding Group A machinery is a sale within s.2(g) of the Bihar Sales Tax Act as property passed to the Contractors.

anchor.surface_text: came to the conclusion by its judgment dated July 13, 1956, that the reference should be answered in the affirmative, namely, that the transaction in question amounted to a sale within the meaning of s. 2 g  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court answered reference affirmatively; Supreme Court upholds after limiting appeal and analyzing contract.

holdings.text: In respect of Group A machinery supplied, the transaction was a sale or hire purchase (sale with repurchase condition), not mere hiring.

anchor.surface_text: the sole question for determination in this appeal is whether, in respect of the machinery and equipments admittedly supplied by the Corporation to the Contractors, it was a mere contract of hiring, as contended on behalf of the appellant Corporation, or a sale or a hire purchase, as contended on behalf of the respondent State. ... Applying these two tests to the transaction in the present case, it becomes clear that it was a case of sale of goods with a condition of repurchase

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance over form; binding obligation to pay approx. two-thirds price; no right to return goods; responsibility for maintenance, spares, and depreciation inconsistent with mere bailment/hire; consistent with title passing subject to repurchase option.

anchor.surface_text: If there is such a right reserved, then clearly there is no contract of sale, vide Helby v. Matthews and others 1 . Applying these two tests to the transaction in the present case, it becomes clear that it was a case of sale of goods with a condition of repurchase on certain conditions depending upon the satisfaction of the Corporation as to whether the residual life of the machinery or the equipment was not less than one-third of the standard life in accordance with the terms agreed between the parties.

precedents.cited_proposition: If there is a right reserved to the hirer to return the goods at any time during the subsistence of the contract, then clearly there is no contract of sale

anchor.surface_text: Applying these two tests to the transaction in the present case, it becomes clear that it was a case of sale of goods with a condition of repurchase on certain conditions depending upon the satisfaction of the Corporation as to whether the residual life of the machinery or the equipment was not less than one-third of the standard life in accordance with the terms agreed between the parties. It is clear on those terms that there is no right reserved to the contractors to return the goods at any time that they found it convenient or necessary.

outcome.relief_summary: Transaction held to be a sale within the meaning of s. 2(g) of the Bihar Sales Tax Act; Corporation liable for sales tax; additional grounds not entertained.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, a preliminary objection was raised on behalf of the respondent that the additional grounds of attack were not open to the Corporation in this Court. It is, therefore, necessary first to determine whether the additional grounds of attack set out above are open to the Corporation. In our opinion, those additional grounds are not open.

Applying these two tests to the transaction in the present case, it becomes clear that it was a case of sale of goods with a condition of repurchase on certain conditions depending upon the satisfaction of the Corporation as to whether the residual life of the machinery or the equipment was not less than one-third of the standard life in accordance with the terms agreed between the parties. It is clear on those terms that there is no right reserved to the contractors to return the goods at any time that they found it convenient or necessary.

anchor.surface_text: the sole question for determination in this appeal is whether, in respect of the machinery and equipments admittedly supplied by the Corporation to the Contractors, it was a mere contract of hiring, as contended on behalf of the appellant Corporation, or a sale or a hire purchase, as contended on behalf of the respondent State. ... Applying these two tests to the transaction in the present case, it becomes clear that it was a case of sale of goods with a condition of repurchase

Applying these two tests to the transaction in the present case, it becomes clear that it was a case of sale of goods with a condition of repurchase on certain conditions depending upon the satisfaction of the Corporation as to whether the residual life of the machinery or the equipment was not less than one-third of the standard life in accordance with the terms agreed between the parties. It is clear on those terms that there is no right reserved to the contractors to return the goods at any time that they found it convenient or necessary.
